reviewText: Unless you're a sexual predator and/or sadistically murderous version of Christmas's Grinch (the Seussian beastie who "stole" that holiday), you'll probably wish to refrain from giving this movie as a gift to a loved one, for ANY celebratory occasion.  Because this is NOT a pleasurable film (at least, not for this reviewer) on ANY level.If you do however, take a finger-licking-good liking to merciless serial killers, hyperpsychotic sexual crimes, and violence so gluttonous, repellent and unnecessary that it forced me to skip to the final chapters of this DVD (not so much out of revulsion as STARK BOREDOM due to lack of an intelligent storyline), well then, don't stop to finish this review.  Buy "Devil's Rejects" now.Don't get me wrong.  The villains in this picture are well enough acted, and they revel in their onscreen crimes the way the Grinch reveled in despoiling "Whoville."  It's just that (and again, please do not misunderstand, I try assiduously NEVER to be a "blue nose," and certainly NEVER for blue noses's sakes!), yet the crimes in "Devil's Rejects" are horrendously gratuitous, and ostensibly for gratuity's sake.  Not that devils such as these DON'T exist in the R-E-A-L world, it's just that watching them in the R-E-E-L world is enough to make even less-than-squeamish viewers (the kind like myself who CAN stomach "True Romance," "Kill Bill," "Sin City," even "Ichi the Killer" - because of their TAUT, TIGHT STORIES!) wretch at the sight of Sherri Moon virtually masturbating gleefully as she orders hapless female victims to disrobe at gunpoint and perform NAZI-esque, humiliative tortures upon one another; or at the sight of Bill Mosely "offing" victims such as Geoffrey Lewis (character "Roy Sullivan") and his buddy (in over-the-top, sick-cruelty-for-sick-cruelty's-sake fashion) by virtue  of no other reason than that they happened to be at the wrong motel at the wrong time.What ELEVATES "Devils" from irredeemability and even gives me pause to give it a third star (actually 2-and-a-half might be just about right) is its ending.  Sheriff Wydell ("William Forsythe"), representing "law and order," "to serve and protect," all that "good" stuff, turns out to be nearly as insane as the outlaw rejects themselves.  Did I say "nearly?"  Okay, AS insane.  When I chaptered forward to HIS key part in the film, where he's torturing Sid, Bill and Sherri at the house from Rob Zombie's prequel to this slaughterfest, "House of 1,000 Corpses," I was piqued enough to watch through to the final closing credits.  And I was NOT disappointed.  Why?Because Zombie does a first-rate job of exploring the hypocrisy (albeit at least SOMEWHAT hyperbolized) between lawlessness and the law designed to put it down.  Law enforcement official William Forsythe is as repulsive if not more so than his three captives; he effectively "out-Herods Herod" in sadism, and one can't help but cheer (as audiences across the world no doubt did and do) when Sheriff Wydell meets his just desserts outside of the Firefly Family Farmhouse at the hands of "Tiny" (Matthew McGrory, best remembered for his brilliant performance as circus "tall man" in Tim Burton's "Big Fish," God bless and God rest his towering soul).And there's more.  Zombie's final scene, where - after Tiny frees Moon, Mosely and Haig, and - badly injured but still "functional" - the three drive their 70s vintage, topdown, fuel-guzzling, V8 sedan down the highway straight into the heart of a massive police blockade.  With zero chance for escape (let alone survival), the music of Lynard Skynard's "Free Bird" wells up as the audience is regaled with old flashbacks of the three villains, in much, MUCH happier times.  One can even imagine these three as once having been regular citizens, not demented goons.  And here is where the film, albeit belatedly, redeems itself for its gory-heavy, story-lite excesses.As the bad guys (and girl) go out speeding into a blaze of gunfire, with "Free Bird" soaring into the credits - one can't help but wonder that there's considerably more to Rob Zombie than meets the eye, or the id.  He's definitely got the goods to make art when he wants to (if, by art we mean, as the Polynesians say, "doing everything as well as we can").  It's just that "Devil's Rejects," unlike a Tarantino film, the neoform-graphic moving artistry of Robert Rodriguez, or the kind of bloodspray classics we're seeing coming out of Japan in the past few years (think "Takashe Miike"), is so anemic when it comes to any kind of thoughtful storyline that we're verily tempted to dismiss Zombie's offerings out of hand.  But we probably shouldn't; because Rob Zombie's movie-making days have, as the Carpenters crooned, "only just begun," and therefore he is to be excused, if not applauded (lightly), for his early oeuvre.In any event, if random, rampant violence (for violence's sake) and sexual predation (for sexual predation's sake) are enough for you, then by all means, Rob Zombie fills the bill just marvily.  But if you want a whole lot more from your cinematic experience, if you want STORY for example, or HIGHLY EXPERIMENTAL horrorplay - then you're much better off skipping Zombie entirely and renting a Tarantino, George Romero, Dario Argento, John Carpenter, Robert Rodriguez, Ridley Scott or Richard Donner flick (to name only a few of the truly great auteurs of the macabre and the mayhemistic).  Because "Devil's Rejects" is the sort of half-baked experiment in "reelism qua nihilism," that even the devil himself might be forced to relegate to the "yawn bin," and perforce REJECT.  Watch this movie then for its first 15 minutes or so, whereupon skip to its ending, and then you, Gentle Viewer, be the ultimate judge, of what a good "(Z)ombie" picture REALLY entails.

reviewText: Though main characters from "House of 1000 Corpses" re-appear, it may not be exactly right to call "The Devil's Rejects' a sequel. True, "The Devil's Rejects" is extremely gory and violent, but the film's entire tone gets less jokey and more nihilistic, closer to that of new American films made in late 60s and early 70s before such as "Bonnie and Clyde" and "Straw Dogs."Am I taking the film too seriously? Maybe or maybe not. Whatever the truths may be, it is true that writer / director Rob Zombie improved his skills. Beware, however, that his improved skills include several torture scenes and killings that will be disgusting to some. Body counts rise steadily up until its ending and so is the cruelty of the characters.The story has not much to tell. Even fans of the film would admit that it is predictable and formulaic. The house of Captain Spaulding and his family is raided by policemen led by Sheriff John Quincy Wydell (William Forsythe). Two escape, but one is captured. The escapees start another killing spree before the final confrontation with the sheriff who prefers to exact vigilante type 'justice' by outdoing what the family had been doing.The acting of the killing family is all in all good - good, I mean, in playing the nastiest and most sadistic characters in a frightening way - but it must be admitted that they are all outshined by underrated William Forsythe doing over-the-top acting which is fun to see. Fun is, I must add, of unique kind.Viewers would find the film too bloody and sick, but some of them would love it for that reason. I was fascinated with Rob Zombie's skills to make relentlessly violent scenes about the relentlessly depraved people, and his homage to the 70s films, using the minimum-scale sets, road movie formula, hand-held camera, soundtrack music and so on. Lots of cameos include Michael Berryman. What else do you expect?If you ask me whether I would see "The Devil Rejects" again or recommend to others, my answer would be probably No. But the watch was fascinating, and I couldn't stop watching it. But I am not sure you will find it the same way.
summary: More Violence and Torture Than "1000 Corpses": Rob Zombie Film in 70s Style and Not Bad at That

reviewText: At the start of the film Tiny is dragging a naked corpse through the woods as police surround the infamous HOUSE OF A 1000 CORPSES. Otis(Bill Moseley) is sleeping with a naked corpse while the rest of the family is roused by the sheriff(William Forsythe) and his men. The family, armed to teeth, exchange gun fire with cops in a scene with maybe one too many close-ups. Johnny Law tosses tear gas into the house. They proceed to go inside the house in a nicely backlit shot that proves to us that Rob Zombie knows how to direct. The family pops out from behind the furniture wearing steel breastplates and facemasks. Another vicious battle ensues and when the smoke clears, cops are dead, one of the Firefly family is dead, Mama Firefly is captured, and Baby(Sheri Moon Zombie) and Otis escape through the tunnels below the house. The police find a 1000 corpses and dub this house "the worst massacre in American history." Of course in America, bigger is always better. Even our killers do it better than anywhere else in the world. What a country!!What follows is Otis and Baby torture and kill some innocent people in a motel(yawn), meet up with Captain Spaulding(the always wonderful Sid Haig) and hide out in a bordello. The sheriff, bent on his own brand of vigilante justice, hires a couple of killer bikers to hunt down and capture the Fireflys. The family is captured and I won't give away the ending. But, in between these scenes nothing much else really happens. Just some detective work involving the Marx Brothers and Charlie(the great Ken Foree) the bordello pimp.If you're expecting the marauding Fireflys to go on a murderous rampage through the state of Texas you'll be sorely disappointed. I know I was. This film doesn't quite live up to the madly surreal weirdness that was evident in HOUSE OF A 1000 CORPSES. The plot meanders along without enough frights or horror.There are a couple of funny moments in this film. Especially the one where Captain Spaulding is gettin' it on with a naked hottie who's straddling him and furiously jumping up and down. Then she pulls a gun on Spaulding and shoots him. He wakes up next to his fat homely lover who says, "Bad dream?" Spaulding says, "About 50% of it." Another funny scene involves the purchase of some chickens and a nosepicking bumpkin who's not quite sure his chickens won't be used for sexual purposes.The violence, what little of it there is, is used in the context of torture, which is mostly disturbing. Women will certainly be disturbed by it. Some of the action, like the knife throwing scene, is telegraphed. "I saw that comin'." The best scene of mayhem in this film is when one of the hapless Firefly victims wanders out into the road, is hit by a semi, and becomes instant road pizza. Nicely done. But, this film could have used a few more scenes of this quality to make it a classic "splatter" movie. Also, the ending is a wonderful homage to BONNIE AND CLYDE.I like Zombie's choice of 70's rock as opposed to the obligatory speed metal which is usually the cliched soundtrack of this genre. That was unexpected. What I DID see coming is the use of FREE BIRD during the final montage. I just knew he'd wait until the guitar soloing in that song to start the final run at the cops. Still, it's a very nice choice for the finale and works well. But, hey Rob, why didn't you use a BLACK OAK ARKANSAS song? This needed some hillbilly grunge for sure.Some of the acting is bad, over the top, and resembled that of student filmmaking. Especially Sheri Zombie and William Forsythe in some parts. Not what I was expecting from Forsythe who's usually a very serene actor. But, it is a Rob Zombie film. Kudos to Sid Haig, who I could watch all day long. I wish Zombie would have made A DAY IN THE LIFE OF CAPTAIN SPAULDING instead. Maybe next time. Haig is the new millenium's heterosexual answer to John Waters' transgender hero Divine. He's just as repugnant, ugly, and perverse.Rob Zombie is a good director who has great horror instincts and sensibilities, but he's not a great screenwriter. This script definitely needed a rewrite or a polish. I hope he options someone else's material in the future and leaves his wife out of his next film.This is WHITE TRASH FILMMAKING FOR WHITE TRASH AUDIENCES ABOUT WHITE TRASH KILLERS. Which ain't hardly a bad thing, ya'll. But, it's only a decent flick about mostly forgettable stuff. Sorry folks, but this one is highly overrated. It's still worth a look.RENT BEFORE BUYING.

Taken on its own terms, "...Rejects" is a brilliant twist on the classic western theme of the law closing in on the bad guys, cornering the villians and ending it all in a bloody shootout, but here, the story is executed with such demented glee, it somehow all seems brand new! Sid Haig is a hoot as Capt. Spaulding (the scene in the car with the little boy is an instant classic) and the rest of the homicidal Firefly clan are played to perfection with special notice going to Zombie's lucious wife in her role as Baby! "Devil's Rejects" is certain to stir controversy for its extreme violence, language and nearly unrelenting cruelty, but that's the whole point of the film and the genre is pays homage to. Try watching this with a sense of humor. The special features are extraordinary: a two and a half hour documentary on every phase of the film's production from casting to the final day of shooting and everything in between, is film-geek paradise! reviewText: The Devil's Rejects was a movie that tried real hard to be cool. The gang of rejects were so twisted and malformed that they were to be not only hated, but likable. reviewText: You would think that killing plus Rob Zombie, plus cool music, plus lots of long greasy hair, plus funky clothing and unshowered bodies, plus blood guts and gore would equal a pretty cool movie but in this case, it just equals a stinker!The movie looks cool but it has NO PLOT! Sure, old slasher movies are violent (and had cheesy effects and didn't look as good) but they had more story and they were scary. This movie wasn't scary, suspenseful or eerie, it was just violent and relied so much on shock value that it failed to be shocking after a while. I would tell you fine readers more about the story but there isn't much to tell. Psychotic and sadistic killers go on a killing spree, there is lots of cool music and it's filmed like a music video, the end. Now maybe you won't have to waste your time watching it!I thought the ending fell flat and I just didn't care what happened to any of the characters. I am all for gore and violence but please, Rob (though you are awesome and talented) next time make it have a point! Personally I think Rob Zombie needs to stick to music and leave acting and screenwriting to people who can actually act and write. I might have liked this if it had more 'meat' to the story, I felt something was missing.I know a lot of people liked this movie and I will say it has some visual elements which are pretty cool so I did give it an extra star for ambiance and appearance. It also had a fast pace and that was good. It wasn't my thing but if you like senseless killing, tons of gore and don't care about the lack of story, you might like this.
